title: 115_hr5709
content: The "Preventing Illegal Radio Abuse Through Enforcement Act" or the "PIRATE Act" enhances penalties for pirate radio broadcasting and enforcement sweeps under Title V of the Communications Act of 1934. The "PIRATE Act" increases penalties for pirate radio broadcasting, with fines up to $2,000,000 for willful and knowing violations. Violations of rules or regulations can result in fines up to $100,000 per day of offense. The PIRATE Act imposes fines of up to $2,000,000 for knowingly facilitating pirate radio broadcasting. The Act also requires the Commission to submit an annual report to Congress summarizing enforcement activities, including efforts to collaborate with law enforcement for fines, seizures, and enforcement sweeps. The PIRATE Act mandates annual enforcement sweeps in top radio markets to eliminate pirate radio broadcasting. The Commission must also conduct monitoring sweeps to ensure compliance and take enforcement actions as needed. The PIRATE Act mandates annual enforcement sweeps in top radio markets to eliminate pirate radio broadcasting. The Commission shall not decrease regular enforcement efforts for pirate radio stations at other times of the year. State and local laws prohibiting pirate radio broadcasting cannot be preempted. The Commission must revise its rules to issue a 'Notice of Apparent Liability' without first issuing a 'Notice of Unlicensed Operations' for violations. A database of pirate radio broadcasting must be published semi-annually. The Commission is required to publish a database of all licensed radio stations operating in the AM and FM bands, easily accessible from their website. The database must include information on each licensed station and entities that have received enforcement actions. Each licensed station and entity must be clearly identified in the database. The curr_chunk discusses definitions related to pirate radio broadcasting, including what constitutes pirate radio broadcasting, the definition of "facilitates," and the term "knowingly and intentionally." The curr_chunk defines "knowingly and intentionally" as being previously served notice by the Commission for unlicensed operations or efforts to facilitate pirate radio broadcasting. No additional funds are authorized for this Act or its amendment. The Act will be carried out using existing authorized amounts.
